{{Infobox former country |conventional_long_name = European Economic Community {{Name in official languages |font-size = 65% |name = (later, European Community¹) |da = Europæiske Økonomiske Fællesskab |nl = Europese Economische Gemeenschap |fr = Communauté économique européenne |de = Europäische Wirtschaftsgemeinschaft |el = Ευρωπαϊκή Οικονομική Κοινότητα |it = Comunità Economica Europea |pt = Comunidade Económica Europeia |es = Comunidad Económica Europea }} |common_name = EEC |_noautocat = yes |status = International organisation |status_text = Sui generis international organisation |continent = Europe |era = Cold War |event_start = Treaty of Rome |event_end = Treaty of Maastricht |s1 = European Union |flag_s1 = Flag of Europe.svg |flag = Flag of Europe |image_flag = Flag of Europe.svg |image_map = Location European Economic Community (1993).svg |image_map_caption = Map of the EEC in the world, at its end in 1993. |capital = Brussels
Luxembourg
Strasbourg² |common_languages = |national_anthem = Ode to Joy (orchestral) |currency = |title_leader = Commission President |leader1 = Walter Hallstein |year_leader1 = 1958–1967 |leader2 = Jean Rey (politician) |year_leader2 = 1967–1970 |leader3 = François-Xavier Ortoli |year_leader3 = 1973–1977 |leader4 = Roy Jenkins |year_leader4 =1977–1981 |leader5 = Gaston Thorn |year_leader5 = 1981–1985 |leader6 = Jacques Delors |year_leader6 = 1985–1993 |legislature = Legislature |house1 = Council of Ministers |house2 = European Parliament |event_start = Established |year_start = 1958 |date_start = 1 January |event_end = Becomes part of a Pillar |year_end = 1993/2009 |date_end = 1 November |event1 = European Communities |date_event1 = 1 July 1967 |event_pre = Treaty signing |date_pre = 25 March 1957 |event_post = Pillar abolished |date_post = 1 December 2009 |today = |footnotes = ¹ The information in this infobox covers the EEC's time as an independent organisation. It does not give details of post-1993 operation within the EU as that is explained in greater length in the European Union and European Communities articles.
² De facto only, these cities hosted the main institutions but were not titled as capitals due to the EEC being primarily an international organisation. }} The 'European Economic Community' ('EEC') was an international organization created by the Treaty of Rome of 1957.Today the largely rewritten treaty continues in force as the Treaty on the functioning of the European Union, as renamed by the Lisbon Treaty. Its aim was to bring about economic integration, including a common market, among its six founding members: Belgium, France, Italy, Luxembourg, the Netherlands and West Germany. The EEC was also known as the 'Common Market' in the English-speaking world and sometimes referred to as the 'European Community' even before it was officially renamed as such in 1993. It gained a common set of institutions along with the European Coal and Steel Community (ECSC) and the European Atomic Energy Community (EURATOM) as one of the European Communities under the 1965 Merger Treaty (Treaty of Brussels). Upon the entry into force of the Maastricht Treaty in 1993, the EEC was renamed the European Community (EC) to reflect that it covered a wider range of policy. This was also when the three European Communities, including the EC, were collectively made to constitute the first of the three pillars of the European Union (EU), which the treaty also founded. The EC existed in this form until it was abolished by the 2009 Treaty of Lisbon, which merged the EU's former pillars and provided that the EU would "replace and succeed the European Community."
